data.title: Gary Dubin, 57, Danny Partridge's pal "Punky"; Aristocats, Diamonds/Forever -- per Wikipedia/Facebook
data.text:
David Carson

wrote:

>https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=1273271019370440

I don't remember him at all. I don't remember Danny having a friend. The

only non-family-member kid I remember from that series is Ricky, the

little bowl-haircut kid who wore primary colors and who showed up for

reasons having nothing to do with the plot of the episode and sang loudly.

Man, I used to watch some bad TV.

--

Dead or Alive Data Base

http://www.doadb.com

RH Draney

unread,

to



Ah, Ricky Segall, the Partridge's answer to Cousin Oliver!...

A non-singing non-Partridge kid was Danny's recurring crush Gloria

Hickey, who wasn't often seen but did appear in at least one episode,

played by Patti Cohoon...the first episode of the show ended with a

cliffhanger of sorts showing a girl drummer who's good enough to be a

threat to Chris, played by an actual drummer named Debra Pearce....

There was also a one-shot appearance by twin brothers Andrew and David

Williams, nephews of singer Andy Williams, where the story had them both

crushing on Laurie....r

That Derek

unread,

to

Looks like a Wikipedia re-hash>

http://deadobituary.com/gary-dubin-american-actor-died-at-57/

Gary Dubin, American actor, Died at 57

Gary Michael Dubin was born on May 5, 1959, and died on October 8, 2016.

He was an actor.

Gary portrayed Punky Lazaar, a friend of Danny’s on The Partridge Family.

Dubin also voiced Toulouse in The Aristocats in 1970 and played the part of ill-fated teenager Eddie Marchand, who was eaten by the shark in Jaws 2.

He played a runaway boy on Green Acres in 1968.

Gary appeared in the James Bond film Diamonds Are Forever in the carnival scene, where he won a stuffed animal and happened to choose the one with the smuggled diamonds in it; Jill St. John, working for the villain, then persuades him to choose another prize and takes it away from him.

Dubin was also a prominent voice actor in dubbing for Japanese animation through out the 90’s to the early 2000’s.

Dubin has also acted in many other projects, his most recent being RockBarnes: The Emperor in You.

Gary Dubin married in 2006, but later separated.

Dubin died due to bone cancer, a sibling of his revealed.

Gary Dubin passed away at 57 years old.

Rob Cibik

unread,

to

On 10/12/2016 12:37 AM, That Derek wrote:

> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Dubin

>

> https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=1273271019370440

>

Gary Dubin (1959 - 2016)

http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/thetimes-tribune/obituary.aspx?n=gary-dubin&pid=181945581

Gary Dubin, an actor who had roles on "The Partridge Family" and in the

movie "Jaws 2," died Oct. 8 of bone cancer, according to his sister. He

was 57.

Dubin was a seasoned child actor when he began appearing as Punky

Lazaar, a friend of Danny's, on the 1970s hit show "The Partridge

Family." His character recurred in a number of episodes from 1971 to

1974. Before "The Partridge Family," Dubin had made appearances on

television shows including "Family Affair," "Green Acres" and "Mod

Squad," with his credits dating back to 1966.

Among Dubin's notable early roles was a voice acting stint as the

pampered kitten Toulouse in Disney's 1970 animated film, "The

Aristocats." He would return to the big screen in 1978 in "Jaws 2,"

playing Eddie Marchand, a teenager who was one of the giant shark's victims.

Dubin continued to act throughout the ’90s and until just a few years

before his death. Among his later roles were appearances on "Beverly

Hills, 90210" and "The District."

Dubin was born May 5, 1959, in Los Angeles. He is survived by his wife,

Marietha.

MJ Emigh

to

On Friday, October 14, 2016 at 7:17:03 PM UTC-5, Sarah Ehrett wrote:

> All you know as a puffer is porn and vulgar slang.

>

> Try looking up "jizz" in the OED.

You mean the bird reference, correct? In this case, however, it IS used in the more vulgar sense. The trailer for the film is somewhat gross, but intentionally so, I'm sure. I haven't looked into it, but it appears that both films were comedy shorts with very small budgets. Just a joke that some may find funny. I probably would have 40 years ago.

Sarah Ehrett's Lesbian Love Interest
